Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca, can't help re your mx but maybe re you nails. I have used Evonail every day since starting chemo on 3 September. All my nails have the white lines but no discolor ring or ridges. My toe nails are perfect. I have no flaking or breaking or pain. I live in France and was prescribed this by my Onc but you can buy it on line - it cost me 23€ and worth every penny. Beast wishes Carol
Posts.Title: Thinking of voluntary MX

Posts.Content: Patricia what a great present, the best possible thing you can do for BC is exercise and now you have the perfect excuse. 30 mins a day with the new arrival will be great for both of you. I try and take my girls out for an hour every day and I know I am doing good for them and me. My little one is a x yorkie and is 14 but now behaves like a puppy when she's out and then sleeps all day. I'm so jealous but my husband won't let me have another puppy. Carol
Posts.Title: Christmas presents did you really think this out

Posts.Content: Hi all, I thought twice about posting this news because I know some of you are going through a very tough time right now but since I always share my bad news (and have had a fair bit of that over the past 6 months) I wanted to share some good news. We went to the hospital today for the results of the lumpectomy and lymph node biopsy and both were clear. There was no DCIS left in my breast and the 7 nodes they took had no sign of disease there or ever having been there. So, it looks like they did actually get everything in July but wanted to be doubly sure before moving onto rads in January. I burst into tears because I was so sure I would need more surgery, poor dr said that had never happened before when he was giving good news. Just incase I got too cocky, he took 175ml off the Seroma With lots of love to you all Carol
Posts.Title: Finally some good news

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies, I m just back from the hospital, the anaesthetist told me that they would be doing a block in my back which would numb me in the whole operated area (he said like at the dentist) the idea is that is gives total pain relief for 24 hours after the surgery - has anyone else had this?  I am in France and it seems pretty standard here.  I'll be having 2nd shot at a lumpectomy and a few nodes taken out.  Carol
Posts.Title: Thoracic Epidural before next Op anybody had this?

Posts.Content: Hi all, I thought twice about posting this news because I know some of you are going through a very tough time right now but since I always share my bad news (and have had a fair bit of that over the past 6 months) I wanted to share some good news. We went to the hospital today for the results of the lumpectomy and lymph node biopsy and both were clear. There was no DCIS left in my breast and the 7 nodes they took had no sign of disease there or ever having been there. So, it looks like they did actually get everything in July but wanted to be doubly sure before moving onto rads in January. I burst into tears because I was so sure I would need more surgery, poor dr said that had never happened before when he was giving good news. Just incase I got too cocky, he took 175ml off the Seroma With lots of love to you all Carol
Posts.Title: Finally some good news

Posts.Content: I was about to write a very sad post about how abaolutely wretched i have been feeling since my second tax last monday. I havent left the sofa in 6 days and am in pain all over my body BUT your post stopped me. We moved to our new house on 3 august (our second move in france) and so our friends here (all except one i have known 20 years) are new. Someone calls every day, people drop in and take my dog out, the freezer is full of soup and frozen meals, on thursday and friday different people came and washed up and brought me lunch and collected prescriptions- the kindness is humbling. I think they might have done a secret rota? One of the men calls my OH every day to make sure he is OK. So, My post today is one of thanks for these wonderful new friends who are helping me get through the worst time of my life. Carol
Posts.Title: Feeling Sorry for Myself Rant

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, I have my fourth Tax on Monday and each of the three so far have produced different side effects. First on was the worst but you will get through it - my worst days 7-10. I ate whatever took my fancy - rice pudding and ham sandwiches and found water very nasty to drink, I drank ginger ale and lemon tea. Lots of soup in Tax 2 and 3. I have been using Evonail on my nails which is transparent but black nail varnish just as good I'm told. I shaved my hair on day 10 as hair follicles were so painful, bone pain can be controlled with paracetamol and only used Tramadol once for stomach pain. Good luck with it, it's a b*****d but hopefully it will do it's job. Carol
Posts.Title: First tax tomorrow, any tips

Posts.Content: Hi, the foul taste is terrible, a lot of ladies recommend pineapple and pineapple juice. I found plain white bread ham sandwiches and ginger ale to be practically the only things that worked for me. The only good news is that by the end of the cycle the taste buds recover just in time for the next cycle. Someone also recommended using a straw to drink so that you don't actually taste anything, but your daughter needs to keep her fluid intake up so try everything. Cranberry juice also was OK and good for bladder health. Good luck and I'm sure other people will post more ideas
Posts.Title: lynzilou

Posts.Content: Thanks but that's part of the problem, I live in France (I lost my job and so we came here with husband's job in December)  and the helpline only takes calls from the UK.  There is a helpline here but I don't think they would understand me nor I them (my O level French has gone off a bit over the last 40 years). The oncologist who speaks fantastic English told me I would have to have hormone therapy, radio and probably Chemo so with such a small tumor I guess it must be a nasty one?  He told me the margins were clear but didn't mention the lymph nodes - seeing the surgeon on 6th so he'll probably tell me the rest of the news then. Did you do Chemo for your IDC? Carol
Posts.Title: Just got call from oncologist not good news

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha. It turns out it is HER2+ and so my worls is yet again in turmoil, they did not get clear margins so it' chemo + herceptrin, then more surgery (probably mx) then radio no reconstruction for 18 months. They will do lymph node in the surgery and have MRI scan on Monday. Feeling sick, crying alot and can't sleep, i am looking at the year from hell and who knows what after that? It isn't fair. Hope you are feeling better than me today because this is just terrible. Carol
Posts.Title: Just got call from oncologist not good news

Posts.Content: Sorry to write this when I know many of you have much harder things going on but the onc just called me to make an appointment, my DCIS is invasive....  I had a 6mm tumor which they said was small and they thought non invasive but turns out it was invasive.  And so I m now Stage 1.  I will need hormone therapy, radiotherapy and probably chemo.  Sitting here crying and alone, waiting for the district nurse to come and change the dressing. Good news is that the margins were clear and so I don't need another lumpectomy but should I ask for a mastectomy?  Will they now take a node or two or three??????? What questions do I need to ask the doctors? Carol
Posts.Title: Just got call from oncologist not good news

Posts.Content: Thank you Sascha, the district nurse just came and said 'Mais Non' if it was aggressive they wouldn't leave you three weeks without treatment, I suppose she is right.  She has several patients who are being treated at the same hospital and she and they are really happy with it. Is the staging of DCIS the same as in breast cancer?  Why is hormone positive good? I am going to ring the helpline now. Thank you again for a voice of reason in my panic stricken world.
Posts.Title: Just got call from oncologist not good news

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha Thanks Sascha mine must seem small fry compared to yours I feel pathetic to be honest. The Oncologist didn't have the report in front of him, he just got a call from the pathologist and wanted to book me in for an appointment before he went on holiday.  He speaks perfect English so he told me the tumor was small, was invasive and he said hormones, radio and probably chemo.  I said so am I Stage 1 and to be fair he didn't actually say yes - but I'm not Stage 0 that's for sure.  I'm in shock and as you know it's not easy in another country.  I can't call the nurse because my French isn't good enough.  I'm seeing the surgeon on 6th so I will just have to wait until then for the whole story.   I asked if will I need another operation and he said no the margins are clear, this is probably why I am in a panic because i am imagining it to be super aggressive if it was so small and yet needs Chemo.  I just called him back and he's gong to call me this afternoon and ask him for a bit more information. Thank you for your support Carol
Posts.Title: Just got call from oncologist not good news

Posts.Content: Hi sarah, keep taking in easy, on monday i walked the dog but since then i have basically been in bed. Currently on day 12 and gp told me i will have s/e until day 14. So even though you feel better take it slowly. Best wishes carol
Posts.Title: 1ST DOCETAXEL YESTERDAY

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah, much better today thank you. Fingers still very sore but getting better and whats more it is a wonderful autumn day, the sun is out and there is the first sprinkling of snow on the mountains. Kittycats post has given me a spring in my step (metaphorically speaking) maybe there is something to the positivity thing after all! Carol
Posts.Title: 1ST DOCETAXEL YESTERDAY

Posts.Content: Virtual support coming from me - hope you get home soon. Carol
Posts.Title: 1ST DOCETAXEL YESTERDAY

Posts.Content: Good to hear from you Pat, and so glad that you are now over all the treatments. Have a fabulous Christmas and wonderful New Year, may you continue the butt kicking into 2013 and beyond! With love Carol
Posts.Title: To Infinity & Beyyyyyyond !!

Posts.Content: I have read the articles you refer to and am wondering what your comments would be regarding my own situation?  I had a routine mammogram, they saw micro-calcifications, did 2 biopsies both of which indicated DCIS noninvasive. In most of the anti screening this would probably fall into the leave it alone school of thought.  They operated and found IDC, HER2+, Grade 3.  I have subsequently had chemo, Heceptin, another operation to get clean margins and lymph node biopsy (all clear and so the op was not necessary but no other way to be sure) and will now have 33 sessions of radiotherapy.  Am I the 1:1,000 that has benefited from the screening process?  Had I not had the operation with grade 3, HER2+ cancer I am pretty sure I would be looking at a quick advancement of the disease, lymph and vascular invasion and mets (I may have all of this anyway).  Had I not had the mammogram the micro-calcifications would not have been spotted since I did not have a palpable tumour, no action would have been taken meanwhile the cancer would have probably spread due to it's aggressive nature.  I do understand your argument re over use of screening, over treatment etc but have always thought how would I feel if I was that 1 person for whom it actually makes a difference?  Please correct me if I am wrong, but I think ironically I am that person.  How do I feel? grateful that they found it before it had spread further, grateful at the speed of the reaction of the doctors and the availability of treatment/drugs and yet still worried about my long term prognosis due to the HER2+ Grade 3 element.  Carol
Posts.Title: breast screening - real facts

Posts.Content: My dear friend, I am so sorry, having had my own trauma of finding another lump this week, I know what you are going through and it is pants. Re the exposure part, I know it is really painful for you and I think about you every time I have radiotherapy, there are no gowns at all and you have to walk through a small corridor to reach the radio room, every time I go I think Sascha would really not like it here. But the staff here are nice and I don't think the see ME they just see a bit of body that needs blasting - I am sure that is how they see you (but I know it's not how you see you). If I wasn't doing radio, I would come over to go to the MRI with you I am sorry I can't. When is your MRI? Your partner will just have to go with you y punto! Lots of love Carol
Posts.Title: Deja vu ????

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, I was in exactly the same place as you, I was lying in bed crying to my husband that I couldn't do it after the second Tax and then I did the third and to be honest it wasn't as bad as the second - then I did number 4 and actually wrote to my dear friends here that death really no longer seemed a bad option I was so ill. Sascha told me to go to the doctor, which I did and I had an infection and was put in hospital. Tax is bloody terrible but for me it was only 3 months of feeling like you do now - it seems like a lifetime but you will get through it. I started doing 4 hourly paracetamol, 4 hourly ibuprofen (something every 2 hours) and Tramadol on the really bad days. My Onc said this is supposed to cure you not kill you so if you need extra meds to get through it ask the doctor. My dear friend everything you have said about Tax is true and I would like to know who thought it would be a good idea to chop yew trees into bits to make the stuff? But it works, hold onto that thought it actually work, hard to believe though that is. I said to my husband that I look in the mirror and just see an older, uglier, balder version of me! He said he thought I looked the same but without hair! I watched old b/w movies on YouTube - night to remember, it's a wonderful life, Dirk Bogarde, jimmy Stewart, mike Todd, lots of wing commanders and jolly women, sheer escapism but really worked for me and no-one gets cancer ever! Lots of love to you my dear and it will all be over soon. Carol
Posts.Title: Don't think I can do another round :(

Posts.Content: Hi, i think i'm having what you're having mine is called TAC I am having 4 sessions and Herceptin which started the day after the first chemo. Herceptin is considered to be more effective if given with chemo (although it is a relatively new thing to give Herceptin to early stage people like us so there is still a lot of research going on). That maybe why it is the TAC chemo we have been given? Also this is called the belt and braces approach that they throw everything at it because of the HER2+. I didnt even have a tumour just a 6mm micro invasion - they didnt even do the sentinal lobe biopsy because they were so sure it was DCIS - i have that to look forward to at next op as they didnt get clear margins. Anyway, grit your teeth, fill the freezer and good luck with the treatment. Carol
Posts.Title: anyone else on taxotere carboplatin and herceptin?

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies, after waiting 2 x weeks for the onc to come back from his holiday I finally had the D Day appointment on Friday.  He started be saying 'Well the good news is that is is HER2+  (not something that I thought was particularly good news having been googling HER2+ for a week) and you can have Herceptrin".  I have Grade 3 invasive DCIS (6mm invasion) and they didn't get clear margins and there is DCIS left but none of invasion (I hope that makes sense).  They didn't do a SNB with the lumpectomy because all the biopsies said non invasive so I don't know if I am Stage 1 or 2.  I did have heart tests, bone scan (I thought for bone density but actually they were looking for Mets which thankfully they did not find) and CAT scan of whole body for the same reason. The plan is first a portocath, then 4 x Taxotere with E  starting on 3 September and Herceptin for a year.  MRI on both breasts after 3rd Chemo and then depending on the results another lumpectomy or mx with the SNB - then finally rads for 30 days.I suppose if the node are affected thy will also then have to do node clearance? He also gave me prescriptions for all the drugs under the sun to counter the side effects; gel for my nails; a wig prescription and a taxi prescription (free to all appointments).  I am seeing the psychologist on Friday. As some of you ladies know I am in France so it's interesting for me to compare the treatment of BC here to the UK where most of you are and Spain where I used to live and where I know Sascha is not at all happy. I don't remember anybody who only had 4 sessions of chemo - it scared me a bit but he assured me it was all I needed.  So, now I'm worried I need more Chemo? I seem to have turned a corner in my attitude to my BC :) Isn't it strange, I have exactly what I had last week but now I have my treatment plan I no longer cry, google or think about BC 20 hours a day - I even sleep through the night.  Carol
Posts.Title: Finally have my treatment plan..... Four sessions of Taxotere with...

Posts.Content: Hi Nikki. I was thinking about you today as i finally left the house (firsT chemo) and was so hoping you would have to go through chemo etc again. Congratulations on your news. Carol
Posts.Title: Feeling upbeat today

Posts.Content: You went CAMPING in the middle of CHEMO???. RESPECT kitty you are my new hero. I haven't had a holiday since 2011 when my husband decided it would be great to go in a camper van from Madrid to Bergen in Norway (i didn't know it then but it was a great preparation for chemo) 21 day holiday, 18 of them in the actual van. On day 7 when we had just crossed our eight frontier my son piped up "when are we going on holiday?". You are the Bear Grylls of Macland! Carol
Posts.Title: TRAVEL INSURANCE

Posts.Content: Hi Lola, if you are having your treatment in France do get in touch with the lovely ladies at Cancer Support France they can tell you what to expect in your local hospital. If it is anything like mine it was like a 5* hotel but with no jacuzzi or bar. A nurse came to help me shower and wash my back every morning and then I had constant attention until another nurse came to give me a back massage at 9pm. The food the day of the op and day before was super bland but by the second day it was duck breast with dauphie potatoes! I wore front buttoning pjs and that helped me a lot (I was having second lumpectomy and 7 nodes out) and had a drain which they actually took out before I went home, they don't like to send you home with drains at my hospital. In the old days there was a period of convalescence after an operation and to a certain degree this still applies in France. As you rightly said they don't do pain so I was topped up with doliprane and didn't need anything else until I got Seroma and cording. I should have kept going with the exercises but couldn't because of the Seroma. I took my iPad and watched UK tv on filmon live through wifi in the hospital google filmonlive Bonne Chance with your op and do feel free to pm me if you want to talk about French things. Carol
Posts.Title: Weeks following mx

Posts.Content: There are no words, i am sending you all my positive thoughts and a virtual hug. Carol
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer for a second time in opposite breast

Posts.Content: I had my last of 4 Tax 10 days ago. I have used Evonail every day since I started the chemo on 3 September and my nails seem fine. I have the white ridges on finger nails, no splitting or flaking and, as yet no lifting. My finger tips are a bit sore but so is the rest of my body! My toe nails have done even better, I think because I they only get washed once a day whereas I am constantly washing my hands. Toenails are perfect, no different to how they were before Tax. On the whole, I think the Evonail has done pretty well. I was given it by my Onc but it's not on prescription so I have used 2 bottles at 23€ a bottle. Carol
Posts.Title: Nail problem from chemo - urgent advice please?

Posts.Content: Hi Shelley, a hug to you from me, I have just had my 4th TAX ten days ago and am still not good. The first TAX was by far the worst, I was depressed and weepy and didn't get off the sofa for about 14 days. My friend came over and offered to wash my hair but I couldn't stand up. I didn't have any of your other problems so please don't beat yourself up TAX does nasty things to both body and brain. The good news is that it does get easier but the side effects seemed to change with each session - this time nose is sore and bleeding all the time, hands sore and I am tired. I don't mean to makes you feel worse just reassure you that what you are going through is par for the course but you will start feeling better soon. Carol
Posts.Title: Why is it all going wrong?

Posts.Content: Hi, I am trying to include anti-angiogenesis food in my diet - see web site eat to defeat. It basically encourages you to eat food that stops the formation of the blood vessels that feed rumors - no nutrients cancer can't survive. I just try and eat something off the list with every meal a 3 portions a day x 365 days is 1000 portions of food that might help. Anti-angiogenesis is a proven technique already included in some types of chemotherapy. At worst. Am eating more fruit and veg and that can only be a good thing. Carol
Posts.Title: cancer and diet

Posts.Content: Hi Tamsin, your friend is lucky to have you:). I have just finished my chemo and I can tell you the thing that made my life easier, four little words "what can I do?" My friends arrived with soup for the freezer, took my dogs out when I couldn't get off the sofa, did the ironing, washed up the breakfast things - just arrived with dinner made for my family. Made me cups of tea when I was too ill to get into the kitchen. I'm sure there are gifts that she would appreciate but you just being there, sitting with her and listening is better than any gift. Unless she has a cleaner may I suggest you go there and say (as one of my friends did) "right I'm here for an hour to be useful, tell me what needs to be done". Chemo is a very hard thing but having goods friends makes it bearable. Carol
Posts.Title: What to do to help

Posts.Content: I am going back into hospital next Wednesday for 2nd lumpectomy (no clear margins first time) and a few lymph nodes out (they didn't do SNB first time) and will ask to see the dietician. My hospital has a research dept on food and environmental factors in breast cancer. The hospital is called the Leon Berard Centre and on the web site (also in English) there is a section on food and diet. But actually the main thing they seem to push is at least 30 mins exercise a day and keeping a good weight with low fat/muscle ratio. I am taking my girls out for an hour a day (not sure about today though due to torrential rain and low temp) but the puppy keeps jumping in the lake and swimming after the ducks amd am worried she will catch cold! I managed to take them out nearly every day even during the Tax but as the weather gets worse here not sure what I'll do during the op recuperation and then the rads. Carol
Posts.Title: cancer and diet

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies, As promised here is what the French dietician from the oncology hospital where I am being treated said to me following all my questions about what I can and cannot eat. I am grade 3 HER2+ IDC. - her2 positive and soya. I was told to avoid soya as there are current studies into Her2+ breast cancer and soya not being a good thing. The are only studies but indications are that soya could actually encourage HER2+ cancer. Just so you know, I have basically given up red meat, milk products, sugar, alcohol and cakes and biscuits since being diagnosed...... - there are no studies that indicate cows milk is bad for cancer patients quite the opposite you need the calcium. 3 portions of milk products a day recommended - they do not recommend that you stop eating red meat - quite the opposite but you need to mix it up with chicken, eggs and fish -Regional, seasonal fruit and veg only and 5 portions a day, every day. She said no need to juice or eat massive amounts of broccoli (as I have been doing) . You should try and only eat food in season and wherever possible from the region where you live. - sugar in moderation - food should be a pleasure - wine no more than one glass a day They recommend a balanced diet with 5 portions of fruit and veg a day BUT exercise is imperative every day, it is the only thing actually proven to help avoid reoccurance of breast cancer. So, that's news to me! I would just stress that this was information given to me asking specifically about HER2+ cancer. But does explain why they just gave me duck breast and chocolate mousse for lunch! Carol
Posts.Title: Soya or not? HER2+ Report after meeting dietician

Posts.Content: Hello Anka, do not google , i mean welcome to the community, its a bit more like a family actually, we have the older and wiser who are well into their treatment Plans and people like you and me just starting out. You will always find care and support and people willing to listen to you. We have all googled, we all regret it, my advice would be do not use any other web page except macmillan until you have your treatment plan. My diagnosis changed everytime i saw a doctor until i started chemo. Due to over googling i went into the meeting withe the oncologist thinking i had a 50% 5 year survival chance (turns out it is 95%). Any statistics you see online are already out of date - a person who is now 10 years disease free was treated 10 years ago and the treatments have changed a lot since then. The waiting is the worst part by far but once you start it does actually get better. And finally, when friends and family offer help accept it, this was hard for me to do but as i am now in the chemo stage it is such a relief when someone comes over with a meal, fills up the freezer, takes out my dogs, does the supermarket run or as happened this week somene came to do the ironing! So, welcome- did i mention dont google? Carol
Posts.Title: Newgirl

Posts.Content: I had also really upped my soya thinking it was actually protecting me from cancer - Starbucks soya latte, tofu etc etc etc . What is excessive exercise? Not that I think I'm likely to be doing it but to be on the safe side. Currently walking the dogs for an hour a day, frankly not upto anything else. Carol
Posts.Title: Soya or not? HER2+ Report after meeting dietician

Posts.Content: Hi Caz, I had blinkin well given up meat and dairy and sat in restaurants and refused puddings whilst everyone else was tucking into creme brûlée! The thing I have been doing is walking the dogs for an hour an day and I guess that is what has kept my weight down, we adopted a small puppy about a year ago who was seriously under nourished and then turned into a red setter (See my ohoto) She absolutely has to have an hour minimum every day so I have to go out. It's the best thing that happened to me (and her) she was also very good at cuddling on the sofa during chemo! Carol
Posts.Title: Soya or not? HER2+ Report after meeting dietician

Posts.Content: Congratulations!  We found a little puppy on the roadside a year ago, the vet thought Cocker Spaniel X but as you can see in my photo she is a Red Setter X and HUGE. When I am feeling down, there is nothing better to raise the spirits than a waggy bottom followed by thousands of kisses.
Posts.Title: Bought a puppy :)

Posts.Content: Congratulations!  We found a little puppy on the roadside a year ago, the vet thought Cocker Spaniel X but as you can see in my photo she is a Red Setter X and HUGE. When I am feeling down, there is nothing better to raise the spirits than a waggy bottom followed by thousands of kisses.
Posts.Title: Bought a puppy :)

Posts.Content: Hi Sassy, I am only 10% ER+ so Tamoxifen hasn't been mentioned as yet. I have the rads to go through next IF I don't need more surgery or more lymph nodes out. I don't even have a next appt with the oncologist. Carol
Posts.Title: Soya or not? HER2+ Report after meeting dietician

Posts.Content: Hi ankah, I might have gone a bit overboard on that advice ......But if I manage to prevent you depressing and frightening yourself, misdiagnosing yourself and becoming an expert on a condition you dont even have (i did all of this) then honestly I will have done you a great service. I say it to every new person but usually not so repeatedly, its something we all did and we all regret. Anyway enough of that, just know I am here for you anytime. Carol
Posts.Title: Newgirl

Posts.Content: Hi Shawshank, I am sorry about what you are going through, I have had 7 Herceptin and no side effects at all. But I have to tell you the fist woman to receive Herceptin in France was given it at my hospital, she was stage IV in 1998 and still comes to the hospital every year for her check ups - that is 14 years at stage IV. There are new drugs coming out all the time and new surgical techniques, with cancer the stats are worthless, because they are out of date as soon as they are published. Trust in you doctors and take their advice, grit your teeth and go for it! We are always here to support you, lots of love to you, Carol
Posts.Title: its spread so scared

Posts.Content: I asked my Oncologist about the fasting and he said it does work but you need to do 10 days before the chemo!  I declined and in fact had to eat during chemo, if not I fell light headed and sick.  I have been told to stay off all vitamins.  Carol
Posts.Title: Fasting Before & After Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Lindy, welcome to our gang and I am sure lots of other ladies will write to you too. Finding out you need chemo is a shock but actually it is the waiting and uncertainty that is the real problem. Once your treatment starts you hardly have time to draw breath. Chemo affects us all differently and I had just about all the side effects you can get even being hospitalized after the 4th chemo BUT you will get through it and the fact you have a support group in your family will help you immensely - plus all of us, to give you advice and encouragement. This past weekend I went skiing exactly 8 weeks to the day since my last TAC chemo - I wouldn't have believed it possible even 6 weeks ago. I have IDC grade 3 and am her2+++ and have had the whole belt and braces approach, I'm starting 33 rads sessions tomorrow. So, it is doable, not easy, but you can do it, grit your teeth, don't google and go for it, it will be over before you know. And when you have those very dark days, as you probably will, we are all here to support you - starting now with a virtual hug from me! Carol
Posts.Title: Hello, I'm a newbie

Posts.Content: Hi Nikki, I had mine drained on Friday afternoon for the third time and I will now try and hold out til Christmas Eve and have it done again as it has already filled up. Snap with the cording ( that is probably a bad use if words re cording) anyway I've got it under the Seroma so can't do much until Seroma stops filling up. The Dr said it's fine and just to keep having it drained until it goes away - have to drive 300kms round trip to get this done. I hope it goes away soon. Can I start rads with cording and Seroma? Carol
Posts.Title: My Seroma won't go away

Posts.Content: Hi Kiera, I had 159ml drained off yesterday that was the 5th time and the quantity hasn't gone down at all. I can't do my exercises because the Seroma is in the way and now I have a cording. It's already back this morning, I can't believe it the dr drained it, expressed more by hand and then drained it again and this morning I feel like I have been kicked by a horse. So, as it is already back, I am going off to the hospital on Monday afternoon to have it drained and corticoids injected into the Seroma. Sleeping still a nightmare and am back on the painkillers...... What a pain in the armpit this is! Carol
Posts.Title: My Seroma won't go away

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzie, I did this plan from 3rd Sept to 5th Nov and am ongoing with the Herceptin.  TAC is a b*gger but it is doable.  I guess I had average reactions, bone pain, skin dry and cracking, hair falling out etc etc.  and like many ended up in hospital for the day with an infection.  BUT it was over so quickly that it seems like a distant memory (never thought I would ever say that I can tell you).  6 weeks after I finished I was up a mountain skiing.  My advice would be make lots of soup now and freeze.  Whenever you have trouble GO TO YOUR GP!  take lots of painkillers if you need them, keep your liquid intake as high as possible.  My hair was growing back before I had finished, I used Evonail on my nails and haven't lost any of them.  Take each day as it comes, my symptoms actually changed from day to day and on my good days I walked the dogs for an hour.  Best wishes Carol
Posts.Title: Any comments/help appreciated

Posts.Content: The surgeon wants to have another look at the path report and is thinking about partial mx whilst i am surre it would be better to chop it off- are you saying it doesn't really hurt? Is it worse than the lumpectomy? If they do an mx no recon for 18 months and i know you have had a hard time with this. I am reeling i think HER2+ is bad news but i don't really know how bad Carol
Posts.Title: Hi, I'm new

Posts.Content: Hi there, for the second time, the new improved site just deleted my reply. I am sorry for what you are going through, but everyone here will tell you the waiting is the worst part of the whole thing. Try not to google, we have all done it and we all regret it. I became an expert on something that I didn't even have. Once you have the diagnosis, you will know what is ahead and we will all be here to support you, someone here will have been through something similar and will be able to help you. In my case they did the lumpectomy without the node biopsy 4 months ago and now I have to have another op and the node biopsy in December ( underestimation of the disease), but I will get through it as you will with the support of friends and family and the wonderful women on this site. Sending you a virtual hug Carol
Posts.Title: advice please

Posts.Content: Me again, only had 40 ml taken yesterday which would have been good news had I not had the the who,e area red and hot and so probably infected. So, am now on antibiotics. Couldn't have the corticoids incase I have an infection but have started exercises anyway. Small Seroma back today...... Will it never end? Seeing physio tomorrow I hope.
Posts.Title: My Seroma won't go away

Posts.Content: Sasha, All the statistics show that cancer treat for BC in Spain is the best in Europe but it is the aftercare you are sadly lacking. There is a precedent in the European health care system that if you require planned medical treatment that is not available in your country you /your doctor can apply to other member states for you to receive that treatment. This has to be approved by your health authority. If you google access planned treatment member states it's all there. Since psychiatric care in English is not available to you and it is part of planned medical care for breast cancer patients you should be entitled to have that in the UK, ditto reconstruction. People from the UK who need planned non urgent surgery frequently come to France where there are no waiting lists. You do need help and you need it in English. If they won't approve England ask to come to France. As you know I didn't have to have a mx in the end but was clearly told if I had one I would not have reconstruction for 18 months-2 years because of the rads so, if that is the same in your case, you could apply to have the reconstruction done here in France or in the UK. This refers to planned medical treatment not the emergency only treatment as covered by the old E11. Sascha, all of us on this board know how cancer takes something away from us - bits of our bodies, the chemo takes your hair and your memory, for many of us it takes our employment and in my case that very much defined who I was. By taking away the possibility to work and earn money some of us find ourselves in hard times, some people have divorced because their partners couldn't take it. What I am trying to say is that people might not be suffering exactly what you are going through, but they are still going through shit that no amount of breast cancer nurses can sort out. We all try to help one another through this board and you above all people know that because you have helped me countless times over the past 8 months. The friends we have here now are really doing their best for you and I agree you have to get yourself back to the UK, what if you just turned up at an accident and emergency dept in London saying you are suicidal wouldn't they have to section you under the mental health act? It might be worth doing just that? Lots of love to you Carol
Posts.Title: Two years....!

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha, I had a coffee with a girl from the UK who had been treated in May for ILC and had a mx and chemo. They did not suggest bi lateral mx to her. What about asking for a second opinion? Thinking about you a lot and sending you my very best wishes. I am bed ridden after 4th TAX. Carol
Posts.Title: Chances of recurrence

Posts.Content: It is utterly miserable, I was in bed last night crying and saying to my husband, what if I go through all this and then it doesn't work? The only way I will know is if I get mets in the future or I don't. So what kind of future is that? Just waiting to see if it comes back? I was wondering if it is a kind of phase we are going through, we're not worrying about the treatment so much now, so we move on (as it were) to worrying about the future? Perhaps with time it gets better? I had an MRI scan last week, (which was clear) but event the radiologist said that after 3 sessions of chemo you would hope it would be clear (door, horse and bolted). Good news in so far as I haven't any visible time bombs ticking in either breast, not including DCIS which I may still have in the left side but doesn't show on an MRI? - op 13th December to have another go at clear margins. The girl I met with lobular was actually from Jersey, she had to got to Southampton for her rads and was in a hotel for 6 weeks, as there is no rads machine on Jersey. Which brings me onto the hair issue. You have never heard me going on about my hair (I had my husband shave it off when it was falling like snow) I didn't even cry and frequently go without my wig, which I hate. But when the girl from Jersey's hair grew back it was wirey (she says like Tom Jones) mine is starting to grow back ( it didn't all go I had a sort of black Velcro stubble since it was shaved) but now I have grey, wirey Tom Jones hair coming through! When I started this nightmare, I had long straight bottle blonde hair, which apparently I can't dye my hair again post cancer treatment. So, every time I look in the mirror I see a complete stranger, disguised an an older, uglier version of me. I don't have the mx scars, but 2 x lumpectomy ain't a good look plus 2 x scars from the portocath for good luck. I was told 'It may be curly when it grows back' and had quite come around to having Boticelli curls BUT Tom Jones (and that is Tom Jones as he is now, not in his 60's hey day). My Mother-in-law was here last week she did make a valid point that one day Cancer may well just be a chronic illness (and gave the example of Aids, malaria, etc all of which used to kill but now can be treated) I hope it's in my lifetime. Love to you from the snowy Alps. Carol
Posts.Title: Chances of recurrence

Posts.Content: Thank you so much this is a great site and her videos are wonderful. Given me hope as my hair is moulting more than my dogs today! Carol
Posts.Title: FAB! Just a fab find !!!!

Posts.Content: I havent seen the ad, but at worst it is a poor call from the art director and the charity that commissioned the job. Mel B is just a face (well and boobs apparently) and if it wasnt her it would be someone else. We are most certainly not the target market, that is very young women who probably think they have no chance of getting BC (founder of coppafeel was turned away by her gp Twice because he thought she was too yoing for BC she is now stage 4) so whilst it might offend some of us, it is designed to get very young women to self examine or get their partner to do so. Frankly, if it saves one life its worth it, young women respond to different things - who ever thought Jade Goody would be a role model for young women and cancer screening? Its just marketing, the magazine probably donated the page and Mel B her time. I suppose on some level its working because here we all are discussing it. Carol
Posts.Title: Mel B´s "campaign"

Posts.Content: Hi sascha, if your Spanish is up to it, why don't you ask for una hoja de reclamacion - i don't even know if they have them in hospitals but if they do it will put the wind up them and if they dont then ask for the equivalent complaint form and take it in person to the head of the department listing all your complaints. Spanish people are pretty regimented in their complaints proceedure so you will need the correct form. You could find out from the internet the name of the director of the hospital and copy him ( its usually a man and is a political appointment so they will not want you complaining either - bad for the image). Suerte y adelante Carol.
Posts.Title: Positive to negative

Posts.Content: Thank you for your almighty post it really gave me hope and made me cry with joy (usually cry for a very different reason as you can imagine) Thank you so much for putting it all down in words. Frankly after chemo i expect you will find the rest of the treatment and lets face it the rest of your life, will be a far far better place to be than in chemoworld. I hope you understand what i mean - it is a necessary evil, but by gum! It is bloody evil. Carol
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: I am at the end of my second week post 4th and final session of Tax and things are not getting any better.  In the middle of the night I woke up with itching welt/bumps on my head, hip bones and arms - I actually thought I had been bitten by mosquitos but it's freezing here so I don't think that's likely.   I also have a terrible cold, sores in both nostrils, nose bleeds, dripping nose, excema on hands and eyes and heartburn.  I was actually sitting crying, not because of the cancer, but because I don't think it would be possible for me to feel worse than I do today.  The puppy got up on the sofa and licked my face so I stopped crying, but I actually now feel for the first time that death wouldn't be so bad compared to this.  I have taken paracetamol for the bone pain and something for the heartburn which hasn't worked, steroid cream on my head, hands and arms but they are still itching badly.  I am alone today, husband at work and all my lovely friends have gone away for the weekend.  I on the other hand have not been out of my house (apart from taking my dogs out, which today I cannot manage) for 2 weeks.  The red bumps are a new symptom, I haven't had that before today, but have everything else on the Taxotere side effects list.  And to top it off my port-a-cath is hurting.  I tried to call the Macmillan nurse but I can't get through from France where I live and no BC nurse here.  Has anyone else had this?  carol
Posts.Title: Red itchy welts/bumps all over head and arms is this another gift...

Posts.Content: Thank you Sascha, I keep saying to people I had no idea it was going to be this bad - how could I?  My husband came home at lunchtime (drove 45 mins each way) and fed me so, I felt a bit better.  I'm using the cream they gave me for the problems with my hands on the lumps and it's helping a bit.  I was expecting this week to be better......  the third week after chemo I always feel better, but this time it's actually worse (I suppose it's cumulative so it's probably built up in my system).  You're right about it being an allergy, it clearly is so I'm drinking lots of liquids and slapping on the cream, I can't see the dr until Monday.  I don't know how to explain the pain of the port-a-cath except if I turn onto my left side in my sleep it wakes me up, when I have the next op I actually will have to sleep sitting up because I won't be able to lie on either side, so that means more sleepless nights.  I said to my husband I actually don't remember the last time I slept through the night.   I suppose we all have our different nightmares to deal with - I'll know mid-December if another lumpectomy was enough or if I'll need a mastectomy.  The frustrating thing is we could be going through all this for nothing.  Thank goodness nobody wants me to be positive ;)  Carol
Posts.Title: Red itchy welts/bumps all over head and arms is this another gift...

Posts.Content: Hi Mary, i was living in Spain until 9 months ago, one of my friends mothers had cancer two years ago and is now a volunteer for the Asociacion espanola contra cancer AECC she is english and goes to hospital and offers support to English people having cancer treatment in Madrid. She tells me there are people like her all over Spain, you should get in touch with your local AECC office maybe there is someone near you who could go with you to hospital? Carol
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Thank you. Sorry to go off subject but have been obsessing over HRT for months.
Posts.Title: New to the group

Posts.Content: I saw the surgeon today and it was double bad news firstly he did not get clear margins, secondly i am HER2 positive. I have MRI scan on Monday then heart and blood tests followed by onc on. 17th. Current plan is chemo with herceptrin, then another surgery probably mx and lymph node biopsy (not done.before due to biopsy saying DCIS non invasive) then radio. I am in shock and cried in IKEA. The tumor was only 6mm but the surgeon took more than 4cm and still that was not enough. Is there any good news in this, i am having trouble taking this all in.
Posts.Title: Different day, different diagnosis. Now it is HER2+

Posts.Content: Hi Kate Do you know how I call the Macmillan nurses from abroad?  I just want to ask how long HRT affects breast cancer chances of occurrence?  I was given HRT by my endocrinologist (I did not ask for it and questioned if I should be given it due to risks of breast cancer) I want to know how long after finishing it it will no longer affect the bc coming back. Thanks Carol
Posts.Title: New to the group

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for replying, we just moved house, i can't sleep, we don't have the phone in and so am online on husbands iphone, he has banned me from the internet as i just keep looking at survival rates. I am just so scared, i called my best friend (a hospital consultant) to tell her and she cried with me. This is a terrible disease, i hope your turns out better than this.
Posts.Title: Different day, different diagnosis. Now it is HER2+

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha, we have just returned from the hospital, been there all day. I had oedema and hives on both arms and my head and was given anti-histamine pills. Whilst I was there I had a blood test and was dangerously low on the white blood count so am now on anti-biotics too. So, am back home not too itchy, hands and arms and feeling very tired as was up at 3.30am with madly itchy arms, head and swollen hands. I just keep saying what else can go wrong how bad is it possible to feel? The drugs are for ten days so hopefully they will work! Carol
Posts.Title: Red itchy welts/bumps all over head and arms is this another gift...

Posts.Content: You have given me the best advice, the most grounded advice over the weeks since my diagnosis and for that I am very very grateful.  I would also LOVE to hear more about your alternative options because many of them are just plain sensible. I have changed to bio diet - following Eat to Defeat recommendations and guess what?  I then discover that the Vaseline intensive care fragrance free that I have been using on my body for 40 years can affect hormones and my BC is estrogen receptive.  So I need your help to try and clean up my act. We are all different, our cancers are different, but we are women going through a nightmare.  We are also entitled to our own decisions on our own treatment - I wouldn't tell you what to wear and I am sure as hell not going to tell you what to put in or on your body.  In short, don't leave, some of us here really need you. Cx
Posts.Title: Not sure if I still belong here or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies, I think I am losing my sense of smell. I know that my sound strange but someone will say 'that smells funny' but I can't smell anything. If I shove my face into flowers I can smell them but most other things I can't smell at all as in 'these scented candles don't smell' when apparently they do... I am on Herceptin and finished chemo in November. Anyone else got this problem? Carol
Posts.Title: Lost sense of smell

Posts.Content: I saw my GP this week and she acknowledged that for me HER2+ the first two years are the time when it is most likely to recur after that the chances go down each year. I asked when do the 2 years start but she didn't know. I will not see my Onc for ages so, I wondered does anyone know, is it diagnosis? The operation (which in my case did actually get all the cancer out)? the end of treatment? (with Herceptin that would be 14 months after the first op) I am a survivor because I am here to write this mail and I am grateful for it but how much of a survivor am I officially? Carol
Posts.Title: When does survival start officially?

Posts.Content: Hi Kate so is that 5 years since surgery? Meaning that it official survival starts after the surgery? I had 6mm of IDC grade 3 her2+ but clear margins and nothing in the lymph nodes. The rest is belt and braces and so I consider myself not to now have cancer. If it comes back in the future it would be bad luck as it was in the first place when it arrived. So then I am officially a 6 month survivor! Carol
Posts.Title: When does survival start officially?

Posts.Content: Babs that is wonderful news, I am so happy for you, we'll miss you! Carol
Posts.Title: best onc app ever

Posts.Content: Hi Debs. My next door neighbor is a five year survivor - she had chemo, rads and surgery. She told me you don't get back to your old self for two years. She is now 63 and in fine form although doesn't go out in the sun like she used to, apart from that she is fantastic! Carol
Posts.Title: When do i get "Me" back

Posts.Content: As I am now about half way through my treatment I just thought I would add my 2€ worth of comment. I am having my treatment in France, where I live. The health service is massively funded (there are 20 specialist cancer centers) but I have been offered and great fully accepted the treatment recommended by my Onc which is pretty much the same as you would get in the UK. I have had 1 x lumpectomy (I will have second op in December as they did not get all the DCIS and a SNB) 4 x TAC and 18 Herceptin. I have had all the scans you would expect including an MRI yesterday with NOTHING on it YAY! My point is that the conventional treatment is global conventional treatment and in France where the health service has huge budgets, the treatment is no different to that you will be offered in the UK. Here there is separate funding for new drugs and if any become available the doctors can offer them to patients without having to worry about the financial implications ( the first woman to get Herceptin in France in 1998 was given it in my hospital and she still comes back for her annual check up). So, even in this utopian health service there is nothing different on offer to what the NHS is offering you - because what is currently available is the best there is at present. It may change in the next few years but I would suggest you take the conventional route it is tried and tested. Carol
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Michelle, I am in France where just about everyone is given a port-a-cath. The installation was not pain free for me because apparently I have a small jugular vein (who knew?) but everyone else I have met had a very easy time. Once in, it takes a month or so to settle down because they move quite a bit of tissue to get it in, but it has never been very uncomfortable but I couldn't sleep on right side to start with. Having chemo and Herceptin is a breeze, I put an Emla a anaesthetic patch on the port when I leave home for the Herceptin and so by the time I am at the hospital I am so numb I don't even feel the needle going in. I can shower with no problem, as the thing is totally under the skin. And best of all my veins are completely untouched. It really is fantastic. I had mine put in on 31August and by November I wasn't having any discomfort at all. You will be so happy you have it. Carol
Posts.Title: collapsing veins in chemo arm!

Posts.Content: Hi Michelle, I am in France where just about everyone is given a port-a-cath. The installation was not pain free for me because apparently I have a small jugular vein (who knew?) but everyone else I have met had a very easy time. Once in, it takes a month or so to settle down because they move quite a bit of tissue to get it in, but it has never been very uncomfortable but I couldn't sleep on right side to start with. Having chemo and Herceptin is a breeze, I put an Emla a anaesthetic patch on the port when I leave home for the Herceptin and so by the time I am at the hospital I am so numb I don't even feel the needle going in. I can shower with no problem, as the thing is totally under the skin. And best of all my veins are completely untouched. It really is fantastic. I had mine put in on 31August and by November I wasn't having any discomfort at all. You will be so happy you have it. Carol
Posts.Title: collapsing veins in chemo arm!

Posts.Content: Please accept a virtual hug from a fellow sufferer thi is really the pits, i am in france so treatment a bit different i am doing 4 tax qnd no fec, believe it or not i thought i was getting off lightly! You have all my thoughts and i do hope they patch you up quickly. Carol
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Congratulations! So jealous and yet happy for you, only people here cqn really know what the words last tax can mean to a girl :)
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: I had my 2nd dose on monday and was told i would feel better this time, but i feel worse. I feel terrible, headache, sick, cant sleep, aches and pains not started yet but my stomach is bad and tastbuds gone already. Can anyone give me words of hope? Carol
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Blimey who would have thought of that! Is the yew tree the ine that smells of cat pee? Carol
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah, I am being treated in France. I had very bad reaction to first Tax and they gave me another drug (sorry I don't know what) then started the Tax again. Altogether I was there 6 hours. Second dose, same thing, third dose was a bit better re the hotness and sweats but they kept going and did not reduce the dose. Tomorrow is my last Tax of 4 I also get Herceptin at the same time. Carol
Posts.Title: Allergic reaction to tax

Posts.Content: I am in third week after tax. I found at end of week 2 i was at my worst and took 1000 paracetamol four hourly and ibuprofen 4 hourly ie something every 2 hours and it worked fine. I drank cranberry juice as also had bladder pain but re mouth it was actually quite nice to drink. My thoughts are with you it is not a nice experience at all, i am having 2nd lot tomorrow and before that husbamd is shaving my head as hair falling out all over the place. Carol
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: I have joined the group, yesterday to be exact, reacted badly to the tax and had to have a kind of anti- dote to it in order to continue. Nurse says the effected will kick in on Thursday once I have finished all the nausea medication. After reading your posts I am now dreading it. They gave me a solution called Evonail to put on to protect my nails and I think I will start wearing gloves when I go out - bald with a wig and with gloves on ... I could be mistaken for Michael Jackson!
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel, I hope you start to feel better and the transfusion does its job. Tax is a nightmare but now a month after number 4, I have started to forget how bad it was - how mad is that? Take it easy and don't be too hard on yourself. Much love to you Carol
Posts.Title: had my 3rd tax and blood transfusion

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel, I can really identify with what you are feeling, I said exactly the same thing to my husband, how can this be happening to me? I still do think it daily, how did I end up like this? 6 months ago I had a biopsy and it has been basically downhill from there. I suppose this is what most people go through? Lack of sleep doesn't help and TAX does screw with both your body and brain and keeps doing its evil job even after you finish. I have been crying all day and am now in bed and I had my last TAX on 5th November. I think everything you are feeling I also feel so I am supposing this is par for the breast cancer course - I had no idea it would be this bad. I don't have mets as far as they know, but grade 3 HER2+ and they haven't yet got it all, I have a meeting for the results of the last op on Friday. I am in agony with the Seroma which is back 2 days after it was last drained and basically can't move my arm cos it just makes it worse. A year ago I was MD of a fashion brand, I am now useless, I can't even put a log on the fire, the lights on the tree or go Christmas shopping (can't lift, raise arms etc etc). This is me cheering you up by the way,.... It's gone a bit wrong. What I mean to say is that I think this is what it's like, my neighbour is a five year survivor and she tells me she went through all of this exactly like us. We just have to hope it gets better soon. To add insult to injury, today all my 'stubble' fell out of my head I had a bath and it was floating on the surface like when my husband shaves (good old TAX) so am now left with grey fuzz, great for Christmas, if they make me wear a hat from the crackers I'll look like a novelty egg. So, my dear friend, we can. Only hope it will get better soon. Carol
Posts.Title: had my 3rd tax and blood transfusion

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca, i was just thinking that you must have had your second tax by now - hope you are better than me. I have been on the sofa for 6 days ans hand have just started blistering again. I live in the french alps and it is so beautiful in the autumn but Im so ill i cant even leave the house! Anyway just to let you know i was thinking about you. Carol
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery - help!

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, I guess you are about 10 days post TAX3, not a great time so I just wanted to send you a HUG and my best wishes. At this very time I discovered ginger ale! It went down a treat although it's not that easy to find here as most people seem to have turned away from dark spirits to gin an vodka (that's what my pr friend told me) so demand for Canada Dry on the wane. But if you can get some, drink it really cold and I found taste was fine and helped me get more fluids. Fluid is not a problem for me now now as have it flowing with gay abandon into my armpit (following lymph removal) and had it siphoned off twice in 5 days (lovely!). Anyway, enough about me :) lots of love to you Carol
Posts.Title: had my 3rd tax and blood transfusion

Posts.Content: Well, I am jumping on this bandwagon, finished chemo 5th November, but as it was as 4th TAX didn't feel very well until December :). Now in hospital after having had 2nd lumpectomy and partial lymph node clearance going home on Sunday. Have missed you Sassy but as fellow tax person can quite understand your absence. Gosh it was May when we all met time has flown by - I am still a step behind you guys until I get the results from this op - clear margins = rads not clear = mx. Frankly after TAX the rest is not hard at all! I am looking out of the hospital window to see HUGE snowflakes like goose feathers falling down from the sky, a great omen for a happy 2013 for us all. I don't want to brag too much but have just had salad, duck breast with dauphinoise potatoes, Brie with organic bread and chocolate mousse for lunch in French public oncology hospital - all that's missing is the wine! Glad to have you back Sassy and much love to you and Kitty. Carol
Posts.Title: Shout out to Sassy and all the amazing lovely ladies on here!

Posts.Content: Hi Kitty, we are near Annecy but I am in the oncology hospital in Lyon. There is so much snow on the road today my husband set off to come and see me and had to turn back 3 hours later as he hadn't reached the motorway! I'm going to ask if I can go home tomorrow but will only be able to go if the road is clear. Carol
Posts.Title: Shout out to Sassy and all the amazing lovely ladies on here!

Posts.Content: Hi Judi, I am with you on this one. I had been living in Spain until last December - annual mammogram for women over 50. We moved to France in December and in May had annual mammogram, which showed microcalcifications, biopsy showed DCIS. I had lumpectomy which showed 6mm of invasive HER2+ cancer. I am now awaiting 2nd lumpectomy and have finished chemo, I am receiving Herceptin. Had I not had the mammogram the calcification a would not have been discovered, HER2+ is aggressive and I could well have had a different outcome. Perhaps the fact that the articles are from the USA where the $ very much drives the health service and women do not have access to treatment if they can't pay for it is relevant? Carol
Posts.Title: screening mammography

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy, it makes sense to me and I don't know if they are talking about DCIS or not and like you I am confused. I had grade 3 DCIS and 6mm of HER2+ invasive cancer so I was feeling pretty pleased it had been dealt with and thought that being given Herceptin was a wonderful thing - am I now supposed to worry that I need not have bothered as will die anyway or angry that I have had chemo? I am not a scientist but have a reasonable education and I don't understand anything. My best friend is a hospital consultant (not Oncology) in a top London hospital, I think she does understand cancer better than me (her husband died of it aged 40) she told me that it was great 'they are throwing everything at it' and I think I tend to agree. Carol
Posts.Title: screening mammography

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn, it is amazing how just when you think you have got your head around one bit of this disease you get blind sided from another direction. Like you I had nothing, went for a routine mammogram in May and now it's November and I've had chemo, one op and await another op in December. They were so sure I had in-situ they didn't do a node biopsy, so now I have to have some nodes removed (sentinel node biopsy useless after 4x chemo). There is nothing much I can say to you except that I am really sorry you are going through this and that we are all here for you. Once they have a true grasp of what you have the treatment will move on quickly and hopefully you will feel better. As I said to my friend yesterday cancer is a bugger! Carol
Posts.Title: Can't believe this

Posts.Content: We moved house four weeks before my first TAX so all the help, dinners, dog walking on chemo days, school run, rugby training and matches (11 year old son) shopping, hair cut, daily visits, phone calls etc etc etc have been from people I hardly knew but who have now become dear friends. My neighbours a five year survivor calls me every week, my best friend from Spain calls every day and will be here for New Year, another friend coming for Christmas all very Humbling. The icing on the cake was a friend who flew from New York for a weekend because he thought I needed a laugh! But best of all is my husband who takes it all on the chin and with a smile on his face. I feel blessed and cursed at the same time - weird. Carol
Posts.Title: Just for fun , the lovely things people have done for you ?

Posts.Content: Good luck with the mx Lola, let us all know how you are when you are back home. I just got my first tattoo today not my idea and not exactly Miami Ink. I keep thinking it's the last bit but it's not really as have Herceptin until August. You will be fine everyone says it not at all painful just the drains are a bit uncomfortable. Lots of hugs Carol
Posts.Title: Last hurdle!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Ethel, it may seem a bit odd to welcome you as you probably feel like one of the gang already :) but welcome! Glad you decided to join us. We're quite a big group going for rads this week, it will be interesting to see how we all get on. I got a pain questionnaire from the nurse, I have to fill it in and take it with me for first actual session next Tuesday- not a very auspicious start to the procedure 'Lets see how much pain you can endure tick as appropriate!" I put that I have very low pain threshold so hopefully I will get loads of drugs! I seem to between two polarized emotions dying and still not really believing I have cancer and expecting them to apologize for the mistake. I suppose this is par for the course? You are certainly not on your own in thinking the worst, lets hope time will help us both get our heads into a better place. Big hug Carol
Posts.Title: Last hurdle!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Karen, I am starting tomorrow, I didn't think I was worried but I must be because I have been waking up at 5am for the last few days. I am working on the premise that it can't be worse than TAC and I got through that OK and to make you feel very happy indeed, be glad you don't live in France I am having 33 sessions! IDC 6mm grade 3 her2+++ and no nodes involved - I think they plan to blow any remaining cells into outer space with 25 normal sessions and 8 boosters. Carol
Posts.Title: Last hurdle!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Jelly, I couldn't ever get pregnant due to hormone problems associated with my thyroid. I realy do know how you are feeling but I now consider this was a) my destiny and b) the best thing that ever happened to me. Why? Because 6 years ago we adopted our son, he celebrates his 11th birthday today and he is the light of our lives. Had I been able to have my children the 'normal' way then this boy who is loving, funny, beautiful, academically brilliant and a fantastic musician and sportsman would have had a very different life and I cannot imagine that I could love any child more than I love him. So, there may well be a chance for you to have children in the future - you may not carry them in your tummy but that doesn't mean you can't carry them in your heart. There are thousands of children in the world who need love and a good home (and many in the UK who need fostering or adopting) the adoption regulations are changing for the better in the UK due to an initiative from Michael Grove (himself adopted). I understand from a friend in the UK in the adoption world that one of the most difficult groups of children to place in foster homes are siblings and that long terme foster care (that is for children who do not go back to their parents but who cannot be formally adopted) is in short supply. Also, my son was just about 5 when he came to us, people asked me don't you want a baby? I said no, I want a child of my own . Here's a little gem from this morning "Mummy do you realise that when you speak French and Spanish you have the same accent?" Me, "that's impossible" Him "It's true, you have an English accent" (falls over laughing) - did I mention he is alo tri-lingual? I am one very, very proud Mummy :). A hug to you, Carol
Posts.Title: Just hit me that there will be no more babies.

Posts.Content: I haven't slept through a whole night since 3rd September when I had my first Tax.  I usually wake up at 4.00am and then don't go back to sleep.  I hope to get back to normal soon but I'm usually hot or cold or in pain or something else is wrong.  Taxotere the gift that keeps on giving.  Carol
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and nights sweats anyone....

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha, you can get headphones with a mike attached, they plug into any laptop (people use them for Skype when they don't want the loud speaker on) you can get them at El Corte Ingles and they are not at all expensive. I bought some for our Mac that has integral mike and they work just fine. It's a grieving process you are going through for what you have had taken away from you both and you need help, don't let this mike thing be another obstacle to you getting someone to talk to. You have to keep plugging away to find someone who can help you get through this. In the meantime you know that you have your friends here who are always ready to help if we can. Lots of love Carol
Posts.Title: Boring.com again

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona, CONGRATULATIONS!  Sooooooooo happy for you!  Carol
Posts.Title: Done it !!

Posts.Content: Hi S. I am day 10 post second tax and my nails are actually better than usual (could be that am now lady of leisure lying on the sofa all day) have no nail bed sensitivity at all and no discolouring or ridges - the only bit of my body which seems to have escaped the curse of the taxotere. Carol
Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage

Posts.Content: Hi Kelly, I am in exactly the same place as you but without the results of the last op -tomorrow is D Day. I had my mammogram with some suspicious calcifications in MAY and still don't know if I need a mx or full lymph node clearance. So, my goal posts keep being moved all over the place like yours from "DCIS lumpectomy + rads" to "I'm so sorry" (that was the surgeon) IDC, grade 3, her2+ chemo, herceptin, another op and partial lymph node clearance. It is both frustrating and bewildering -part of me thinks "these people are experts how can they not know what is wrong with me" to "they won't know until the results come backin 15 days because without the lab results it's just guess work" It's just a case of having to wait, do what they say and hope for the best. Not ideal, but at least the chemo is over and that is the worst bit. The only consolation is that nobody is expecting a Christmas card from me this year! Carol
Posts.Title: Not great news

Posts.Content: Goodmorning all, as some of you know i live in France and have slightly different treatment to the uk - no fec but 4 x taxotere. The onc gave me a prescription for Evonail to paint on my finger and toenails and the surrounding skin each morning which i have religiously done. It is a clear liquid in nail varnish size bottle but doesnt smell at all. Anyway, 13 days post first Tax and my nails have never been better. All strong, good colour with no discolouration or ridges at all. Lily the puppy ate the box but it is made in france by EVAUX LAbs. It protects the nails from ultraviolet - in the good old day just after the chemo when i could still walk the dogs i did wear gloves (paranoia about losing nails) but my friend recommended i just see if the Evonail works and it does seem to. It wasnt covered by the social security so i paid 23€ for it, so far so good. Carol
Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage

Posts.Content: Tips of fingers could be start of dermatitis - i got it day 8 and by day 9 had blisters all over both hands. If it gets worse go to the doctor - i have cortisone cream and am almost back to normal 5 days later (at one stage couldnt even hold a cup of tea or take top off the toothpaste). Dont want to scare you but it can also affect the feet so keep a look out. It doesnt affect everyone so you maybe lucky. Another chemo pothole on the road of life i'm afraid. Carol
Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage

Posts.Content: Hi Lorraine, I am being treated at the Leon Berard Cancer Centre in Lyon and wasn't offered the mitts (have seen people with cold cap but no-one with mitts).  Good luck with the Tax tomorrow is my last of 4, the first was the worst by far, I had all the classic side effects but it did get better with the second and third session.  I found Ginger Ale to be quite good once everything started tasting like a rusty bucket!  My diet consisted of rice pudding and ham sandwiches (so much for no dairy, ham or white bread) it was all I could manage.  Once I am over the Tax I'll go back on the fruit and veg.  I don't know about the nail varnish sorry.  Take lots of paracetamol and if the pains get bad take 4 hourly paracetamol and four hourly ibuprofen (something every two hours) you don't have to suffer.  In the second Tax my abdominal pain was so bad I took the tramadol they gave me for the first op.  I have second op pending and then rads in the New Year.  I'm near Annecy.  Carol
Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca, how did you get so far ahead of me I don't start rads until next week! Anyway, check out a blog called Sophie feels better, it is written by Sophie Beresiner ex beauty editor from Look magazine now at Elle, she had BC and this is about how to look good and feel better during treatment inc skin care advice and brands she recommends. Hope it helps Carol
Posts.Title: Skin care recommendations, please

Posts.Content: I'm going again tomorrow morning for my 4th draining have tennis ball under my arm, you can moan cos it is uncomfortable and then painful, you can't sleep properly and you armpit probably smells like mine YUK! Carol
Posts.Title: Back to hospital

Posts.Content: So, happy for you. I found that outing a soft pillow or even better one of those neck pillows that you use for traveling, under my arm helped a lot when lying on the sofa or in bed. Take it easy, you have just had an op and drink lots to flush out all the drugs :). Carol
Posts.Title: update on my op yesterday which I was really anxious about

Posts.Content: I had a lumpectomy and lymph node dissection on 6th December and yesterday a big lump appeared under my arm, very, very painful.  The district nurse sent me to hospital where they drained 100ml and now I am like a new woman, what a relief!  Carol
Posts.Title: Seroma after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel, I have just been to hospital to have fluid drawn off armpit (nice), it's a never ending story....  hope you feel better soon Carol
Posts.Title: How long before you feel better after blood transfusion?

Posts.Content: Thanks Keira, you can top up now with the champagne! So happy for you, clean scans is really great news. Carol
Posts.Title: Back to hospital
